plants.name: Crocus vernus
plants.description: A small, bulbous perennial known for its vibrant cup-shaped flowers that often appear in late winter to early spring, signaling the end of the cold season.
plants.location: Temperate regions of Europe and North America (often cultivated)
plants.funFact: Crocus vernus bulbs were historically used to produce saffron-like dyes, although true saffron comes from Crocus sativus.

plants.name: Helleborus niger
plants.description: An evergreen perennial famous for its white flowers that bloom in the cold winter months, often around Christmas through early spring, providing early nectar sources for pollinators.
plants.location: Mountainous regions of central and southern Europe
plants.funFact: Despite its name, the Christmas Rose is not a true rose but belongs to the buttercup family, Ranunculaceae.

plants.name: Acacia baileyana
plants.description: An Australian native tree species appreciated for its bright yellow, fluffy flower heads that bloom in late winter and early spring, often brightening the landscape.
plants.funFact: Acacia baileyana blooms are an important early food source for native bees during Australia's drier months.

plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: A popular evergreen shrub in temperate gardens, prized for its large, rose-like flowers that bloom from late fall into early spring, often in shades of pink, red, and white.
plants.funFact: Camellia japonica was one of the first plants exported from East Asia to Europe, becoming a symbol of elegance in Victorian gardens.
